body:
> Then where are they? Because I don't know of any Democrat neocons.

Are you kidding? All the old neocons have been shilling for Biden and the neoliberal establishment since last year. Bill Kristol and Max Boot are the worst of the bunch. (Here's Max Boot saying "Not electing Hillary Clinton was one of the worst blunders in U.S. history." https://nitter.snopyta.org/MaxBoot/status/1369413053666779141)

https://www.theamericanconservative.com/state-of-the-union/the-neocons-exit-stage-left/

https://pjmedia.com/columns/mark-ellis/2020/09/18/never-trump-war-pigs-n941531

https://reason.com/2020/08/19/gop-hawks-are-turning-out-for-biden/

https://publicseminar.org/essays/the-rotten-alliance-of-liberals-and-neocons-will-likely-shape-u-s-foreign-policy-for-years-to-come-biden-kagan/

> Neoliberalism doesn't go far enough in my opinion. I still consider it somewhat authoritarian.

Of course it's authoritarian. Neoliberalism in practice takes only the parts of libertarianism that benefits the elite, and marries it with only the parts of socialism that benefit the elite. It is an attempt to destroy the nation-state and force people into a globalist regime managed by a handful of well-connected plutocrats.

body:
That was the theory. The neoliberalism of the Reagan and Thatcher era came about because the welfare system was crumbling, the unions had become greedy and stagnant, and increasing oil prices were weighing on the economy, amplifying the problems. Much needed reforms were put in place, oil prices dropped, and then the USSR finally failed, so it looked like neoliberalism was a miracle. The problem is that it isn't really a coherent ideology (not that anything is; everything is flexible in reality) and during the good times of the 90s the establishment started using "privatization" and "deregulation" as tools for hooking up their friends with backroom deals, instead of using them as tools to unstick a broken economy. This coupled with the post-USSR push for globalism led to all the outsourcing to China and the destruction of the US manufacturing economy. At least this is my take.

I think most influential people who seem to be "neoliberal" these days are actually what some have called a "liberaltarian": https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/insights/rise-liberaltarian
body_html:
That was the theory. The neoliberalism of the Reagan and Thatcher era came about because the welfare system was crumbling, the unions had become greedy and stagnant, and increasing oil prices were weighing on the economy, amplifying the problems. Much needed reforms were put in place, oil prices dropped, and then the USSR finally failed, so it looked like neoliberalism was a miracle. The problem is that it isn't really a coherent ideology (not that anything is; everything is flexible in reality) and during the good times of the 90s the establishment started using "privatization" and "deregulation" as tools for hooking up their friends with backroom deals, instead of using them as tools to unstick a broken economy. This coupled with the post-USSR push for globalism led to all the outsourcing to China and the destruction of the US manufacturing economy. At least this is my take.

I think most influential people who seem to be "neoliberal" these days are actually what some have called a "liberaltarian": https://www.gsb.stanford.edu/insights/rise-liberaltarian
